segment.source: Follow these guidelines to prepare your app's packages for submission to the Windows Store.
segment.target: Follow these guidelines to prepare your app's packages for submission to the Windows Store.

segment.source: App package requirements
segment.target: App package requirements

segment.source: App package requirements
segment.target: App package requirements

segment.source: Follow these guidelines to prepare your app's packages for submission to the Windows Store.
segment.target: Follow these guidelines to prepare your app's packages for submission to the Windows Store.

segment.source: Before you build your app's package for the Windows Store
segment.target: Before you build your app's package for the Windows Store

segment.source: Make sure to test your app with the Windows App Certification Kit.
segment.target: Make sure to test your app with the Windows App Certification Kit.

segment.source: We also recommend that you test your app on different types of hardware.
segment.target: We also recommend that you test your app on different types of hardware.

segment.source: Note that until we certify your app and make it available from the Windows Store, it can only be installed and run on computers that have developer licenses.
segment.target: Note that until we certify your app and make it available from the Windows Store, it can only be installed and run on computers that have developer licenses.

segment.source: Building the app package using Microsoft Visual Studio
segment.target: Building the app package using Microsoft Visual Studio

segment.source: If you're using Microsoft Visual Studio as your development environment, you already have built-in tools that make creating an app package a quick and easy process.
segment.target: If you're using Microsoft Visual Studio as your development environment, you already have built-in tools that make creating an app package a quick and easy process.

segment.source: For more info, see Packaging apps.
segment.target: For more info, see Packaging apps.

segment.source: Note Be sure that all your filenames use ANSI.
segment.target: Note Be sure that all your filenames use ANSI.

segment.source: When you create your package in Visual Studio, make sure you are signed in with the same Microsoft account associated with your developer account.
segment.target: When you create your package in Visual Studio, make sure you are signed in with the same Microsoft account associated with your developer account.

segment.source: Some parts of the package manifest have specific details related to your account.
segment.target: Some parts of the package manifest have specific details related to your account.

segment.source: This info is detected and added automatically.
segment.target: This info is detected and added automatically.

segment.source: When you build your app's packages, Visual Studio can create an .appx file or an .appxupload file (or a .xap file for Windows Phone 8.1 and earlier).
segment.target: When you build your app's packages, Visual Studio can create an .appx file or an .appxupload file (or a .xap file for Windows Phone 8.1 and earlier).

segment.source: For apps that target Windows 10, always upload the .appxupload file in the Packages page.
segment.target: For apps that target Windows 10, always upload the .appxupload file in the Packages page.

segment.source: For more info about packaging UWP apps for the Store, see Packaging Universal Windows apps for Windows 10.
segment.target: For more info about packaging UWP apps for the Store, see Packaging Universal Windows apps for Windows 10.

segment.source: Your app's packages don't have to be signed with a certificate rooted in a trusted certificate authority.
segment.target: Your app's packages don't have to be signed with a certificate rooted in a trusted certificate authority.

segment.source: App bundles
segment.target: App bundles

segment.source: For apps that target Windows 8.1, Windows Phone 8.1, and later, Visual Studio can generate an app bundle (.appxbundle) to reduce the size of the app that users download.
segment.target: For apps that target Windows 8.1, Windows Phone 8.1, and later, Visual Studio can generate an app bundle (.appxbundle) to reduce the size of the app that users download.

segment.source: This can be helpful if you've defined language-specific assets, a variety of image-scale assets, or resources that apply to specific versions of Microsoft DirectX.
segment.target: This can be helpful if you've defined language-specific assets, a variety of image-scale assets, or resources that apply to specific versions of Microsoft DirectX.

segment.source: Note One app bundle can contain your packages for all architectures.
segment.target: Note One app bundle can contain your packages for all architectures.

segment.source: You should submit only one bundle for each targeted OS.
segment.target: You should submit only one bundle for each targeted OS.

segment.source: With an app bundle, a user will only download the relevant files, rather than all possible resources.
segment.target: With an app bundle, a user will only download the relevant files, rather than all possible resources.

segment.source: For more info about app bundles, see Packaging apps and Packaging Universal Windows apps for Windows 10.
segment.target: For more info about app bundles, see Packaging apps and Packaging Universal Windows apps for Windows 10.

segment.source: Building the app package manually
segment.target: Building the app package manually

segment.source: If you don't use Visual Studio to create your package, you must create your package manifest manually.
segment.target: If you don't use Visual Studio to create your package, you must create your package manifest manually.

segment.source: Be sure to review the App package manifest documentation for complete manifest details and requirements.
segment.target: Be sure to review the App package manifest documentation for complete manifest details and requirements.

segment.source: Your manifest must follow the package manifest schema in order to pass certification.
segment.target: Your manifest must follow the package manifest schema in order to pass certification.

segment.source: Your manifest must include some specific info about your account and your app.
segment.target: Your manifest must include some specific info about your account and your app.

segment.source: You can find this info by looking at View app identity details in the App management section of your app's overview page in the dashboard.
segment.target: You can find this info by looking at View app identity details in the App management section of your app's overview page in the dashboard.

segment.source: Note Values in the manifest are case-sensitive.
segment.target: Note Values in the manifest are case-sensitive.

segment.source: Spaces and other punctuation must also match.
segment.target: Spaces and other punctuation must also match.

segment.source: Enter the values carefully and review them to ensure that they are correct.
segment.target: Enter the values carefully and review them to ensure that they are correct.

segment.source: App bundles use a different manifest.
segment.target: App bundles use a different manifest.

segment.source: Review the Bundle manifest documentation for the details and requirements for app bundle manifests.
segment.target: Review the Bundle manifest documentation for the details and requirements for app bundle manifests.

segment.source: Tip Be sure to run the Windows App Certification Kit before you submit your packages.
segment.target: Tip Be sure to run the Windows App Certification Kit before you submit your packages.

segment.source: This can you help determine if your manifest has any problems that might cause certification or submission failures.
segment.target: This can you help determine if your manifest has any problems that might cause certification or submission failures.

segment.source: If your app has more than one package, these app manifest elements must be the same in each package (per targeted OS):
segment.target: If your app has more than one package, these app manifest elements must be the same in each package (per targeted OS):

segment.source: Package/Capabilities
segment.target: Package/Capabilities

segment.source: Package/Dependencies
segment.target: Package/Dependencies

segment.source: Package/Resources
segment.target: Package/Resources

segment.source: Package format requirements
segment.target: Package format requirements

segment.source: Your app’s packages must comply with these requirements.
segment.target: Your app’s packages must comply with these requirements.

segment.source: App package property
segment.target: App package property

segment.source: Requirement
segment.target: Requirement

segment.source: Package size
segment.target: Package size

segment.source: .appxbundle: 25 GB maximum per bundle
segment.target: .appxbundle: 25 GB maximum per bundle

segment.source: .appx packages targeting Windows 8.1: 8 GB maximum per package
segment.target: .appx packages targeting Windows 8.1: 8 GB maximum per package

segment.source: .appx packages targeting Windows 8: 2 GB maximum per package
segment.target: .appx packages targeting Windows 8: 2 GB maximum per package

segment.source: .appx packages targeting Windows Phone 8.1: 4 GB maximum per package
segment.target: .appx packages targeting Windows Phone 8.1: 4 GB maximum per package

segment.source: .xap packages: 1 GB maximum per package
segment.target: .xap packages: 1 GB maximum per package

segment.source: Block map hashes
segment.target: Block map hashes

segment.source: SHA2-256 algorithm
segment.target: SHA2-256 algorithm

segment.source: StoreManifest XML file
segment.target: StoreManifest XML file

segment.source: StoreManifest.xml is an optional configuration file that may be included in app packages.
segment.target: StoreManifest.xml is an optional configuration file that may be included in app packages.

segment.source: Its purpose is to enable features, such as declaring your app as a Windows Store device app or declaring requirements that a package depends on to be applicable to a device, that the package manifest does not cover.
segment.target: Its purpose is to enable features, such as declaring your app as a Windows Store device app or declaring requirements that a package depends on to be applicable to a device, that the package manifest does not cover.

segment.source: StoreManifest.xml is submitted with the app package and must be in the root folder of your app's main project.
segment.target: StoreManifest.xml is submitted with the app package and must be in the root folder of your app's main project.

segment.source: For more info, see StoreManifest schema.
segment.target: For more info, see StoreManifest schema.
